User

Contains subroutines to provide for user interaction while running a program.

Functions
AlertArgs
call User.AlertArgs(
message,
argumentsArray
);

Display a pop up box in a running program which requires user input to continue

Parameters
message

the text displayed in the message box

argumentsArray

an array of length 24, containing format arguments corresponding with placeholder strings in message.  These placeholder values are of the form {0}, {1}, ..., {23}.

Example
local argumentsArray(24);
argumentsArray(0) = "Close ";
argumentsArray(1) = "the ";
argumentsArray(2) = "door ";
argumentsArray(3) = "before ";
argumentsArray(4) = "continuing";
call User.AlertArgs("Please {0} {1} {2} {3} {4}.", argumentsArray(0));
Alert
call User.Alert(
message
);

Display a pop up box in a running program which requires user input to continue

Parameters
message

the text displayed in the message box

Example
call User.Alert("Verify the fumex is on");
Alert1
call User.Alert1(
message,
argument1
);

Display a pop up box in a running program which requires user input to continue.  The message contains one format argument, in the form of '{0}'

Parameters
message

the text displayed in the message box

argument1

the first text substitution

Example
local message = "Warning - the laser power is at {0}" ;   //{0} will be substituted by argument 1
local laserPowerPercentage = "zero percent";
call User.Alert1(message, laserPowerPercentage);         //displays "Warning - the laser power is at zero percent"
Alert2
call User.Alert2(
message,
argument1,
argument2
);

Displays a pop up box in a running program requiring user input to continue.  The message contains two format arguments.

Parameters
message

the text displayed in the message box

argument1

the first text substitution

argument2

the second text substitution

Example
local message = "{0} - the laser power is at {1}%";
local messageType = "Warning";
local laserPowerPercentage = "10 percent";
call User.Alert2(message, messageType, laserPowerPercentage);         //displays "Warning - the laser power is at 10 percent"
Alert3
call User.Alert3(
message,
argument1,
argument2,
argument3
);

Displays a pop up box in a running program requiring user input to continue.  The message contains three format arguments.

Parameters
message

the text displayed in the message box

argument1

the first text substitution

argument2

the second text substitution

argument3

the third text substitution

Alert4
call User.Alert4(
message,
argument1,
argument2,
argument3,
argument4
);

Displays a pop up box in a running program requiring user input to continue.  The message contains four format arguments.

Parameters
message

the text displayed in the message box

argument1

the first text substitution

argument2

the second text substitution

argument3

the third text substitution

argument4

the fourth text substitution

Alert5
call User.Alert5(
message,
argument1,
argument2,
argument3,
argument4,
argument5
);

Displays a pop up box in a running program requiring user input to continue.

Parameters

message is the string to display to the user

argument1 is the first text substitution

argument2 is the second text substitution

argument3 is the third text substitution

argument4 is the fourth text substitution

argument5 is the fifth text substitution

YesNoArgs
call User.YesNoArgs(
message,
argumentsArray,
&yesOrNo
);

Displays a yes or no pop up box in a running program requiring user input to continue.

Parameters
message

the text displayed in the message box

argumentsArray

an array of length 24, containing format arguments corresponding with placeholder strings in message.  These placeholder values are of the form {0}, {1}, ..., {23}.  Response Parameters:

&yesOrNo

set to 1 if the user pressed "Yes" and 0 if the user pressed "No"

Example
local argumentsArray(24);
local yesOrNo;
argumentsArray(0) = "Close ";
argumentsArray(1) = "the ";
argumentsArray(2) = "door ";
argumentsArray(3) = "before ";
argumentsArray(4) = "continuing";
call User.YesNoArgs("Please {0} {1} {2} {3} {4}.", argumentsArray(0), &yesOrNo);
YesNo
call User.YesNo(
message,
&yesOrNo
);

Displays a yes or no pop up box in a running program requiring user input to continue

Parameters
message

the text displayed in the message box

Response Parameters
&yesOrNo

set to 1 if the user pressed "Yes" and 0 if the user pressed "No"

Example
local yesOrNo;
call User.YesNo("Is the fumex is on?", &yesOrNo);
YesNo1
call User.YesNo1(
message,
argument1,
&yesOrNo
);

Displays a yes or no pop up box in a running program requiring user input to continue.  The message accepts one format argument.

Parameters
message

the text displayed in the message box

argument1

the first text substitution

Response Parameters
&yesOrNo

set to 1 if the user pressed "Yes" and 0 if the user pressed "No"

Example
local yesOrNo;
local message = "Is the laser power at {0}?" ;   //{0} will be substituted by argument 1
local laserPowerPercentage = "zero percent";
call User.YesNo1(message, laserPowerPercentage, &yesOrNo);         //displays "Is the laser power at zero percent?"
YesNo2
call User.YesNo2(
message,
argument1,
argument2,
&yesOrNo
);

Displays a yes or no pop up box in a running program requiring user input to continue.  The message accepts two format arguments.

Parameters
message

the text displayed in the message box

argument1

the first text substitution

argument2

the second text substitution

Response Parameters
&yesOrNo

set to 1 if the user pressed "Yes" and 0 if the user pressed "No"

Example
local yesOrNo;
local message = "Is the {0} at {1}?";
local laserPowerString = "laser power";
local laserPowerPercentage = "10 percent";
call User.YesNo2(message, laserPowerString, laserPowerPercentage, &yesOrNo);         //displays "Is the laser power at 10 percent?"
YesNo3
call User.YesNo3(
message,
argument1,
argument2,
argument3,
&yesOrNo
);

Displays a yes or no pop up box in a running program requiring user input to continue.  The message accepts three format arguments.

Parameters
message

the text displayed in the message box

argument1

the first text substitution

argument2

the second text substitution

argument3

the third text substitution

Response Parameters
&yesOrNo

set to 1 if the user pressed "Yes" and 0 if the user pressed "No"

argument1,

&yesOrNo
);

Parameters

the first text substitution

the second text substitution

the third text substitution

the fourth text substitution Response Parameters

&yesOrNo

message,
argument1,
argument2,
argument3,
argument4,
argument5,
&yesOrNo
);

Displays a yes or no pop up box in a running program requiring user input to continue. The message accepts five format arguments.

Parameters
message

the text displayed in the message box

argument1

the first text substitution

argument2

the second text substitution

argument3

the third text substitution

argument4

the fourth text substitution

argument5

the fifth text substitution

Response Parameters
&yesOrNo

set to 1 if the user pressed "Yes" and 0 if the user pressed "No"

RequestInputArgs
call User.RequestInputArgs(
message,
argumentsArray,
&userInput
);

Raises a message box in a running program requiring the user to input a numeric value to continue.

Parameters
message

the text displayed in the message box

argumentsArray

an array of length 24, containing format arguments corresponding with placeholder strings in message.  These placeholder values are of the form {0}, {1}, ..., {23}.  Response Parameters:

&userInput

the numeric input entered by the user into the message box

Example
local userInput;
local argumentsArray(24);
argumentsArray(0) = "Enter";
argumentsArray(1) = "the";
argumentsArray(2) = "pulse";
argumentsArray(3) = "rate";
argumentsArray(4) = "in millimeters:";
call User.RequestInputArgs("{0} {1} {2} {3} {4}", argumentsArray(0), &userInput);
RequestInput
call User.RequestInput(
message,
&userInput
);

Raises a message box in a running program requiring the user to input a numeric value to continue.

Parameters
message

the text displayed in the message box

Response Parameters
&userInput

the numeric input entered by the user into the message box

Example
local userInput;
call User.RequestInput("What is the fixture height in millimeters?", &userInput);
RequestInput1
call User.RequestInput1(
message,
argument1,
&userInput
);

Raises a message box in a running program requiring the user to input a numeric value to continue.  The message has one text substitution.

Parameters
message

the text displayed in the message box

argument1

the first text substitution

Response Parameters
&userInput

the numeric input entered by the user into the message box

Example
local userInput;
local message = "What is the fixture height in {0}" ;   //{0} will be substituted by argument 1
local unitOfMeasurement = "millimeters?";
call User.RequestInput1(message, unitOfMeasurement, &userInput);         //displays "What is the fixture height in millimeters?"
RequestInput2
call User.RequestInput2(
message,
argument1,
argument2,
&userInput
);

Raises a message box in a running program requiring the user to input a numeric value to continue.  The message has two text substitutions.

Parameters
message

the text displayed in the message box

argument1

the first text substitution

argument2

the second text substitution

Response Parameters
&userInput

the numeric input entered by the user into the message box

Example
local userInput;
local message = "What is the {0} in {1}";
local fixtureHeight = "fixture height";
local unitOfMeasurement = "millimeters?";
call User.RequestInput2(message, fixtureHeight, unitOfMeasurement, &userInput);         //displays "What is the fixture height in millimeters?"
RequestInput3
call User.RequestInput3(

RequestTextInputArgs

Raises a message box in a running program requiring the user to input text to continue.

Parameters
message

the text displayed in the message box

argumentsArray

an array of length 24, containing format arguments corresponding with placeholder strings in message.  These placeholder values are of the form {0}, {1}, ..., {23}.  Response Parameters:

&userInput

the text entered by the user into the message box

Example
local userInput;
local argumentsArray(24);
argumentsArray(0) = "Enter";
argumentsArray(1) = "the";
argumentsArray(2) = "pulse";
argumentsArray(3) = "rate";
argumentsArray(4) = "in millimeters:";
call User.RequestInputArgs("{0} {1} {2} {3} {4}", argumentsArray(0), &userInput);

call User.RequestTextInput(
message,
&userInput
);

Raises a message box in a running program requiring the user to input text to continue.

Parameters

the text displayed in the message box

Response Parameters
&userInput

the text entered by the user into the message box

call User.RequestTextInput("What is the fixture height in millimeters?", &userInput);
RequestTextInput1
call User.RequestTextInput1(
message,
argument1,
&userInput
);

Raises a message box in a running program requiring the user to input text to continue.  The message allows one format argument.

Parameters
message

the text displayed in the message box

argument1

the first text substitution

Response Parameters

&userInput is the text entered by the user into the message box

Example
local userInput;
local message = "What is the fixture height in {0}" ;   //{0} will be substituted by argument 1
local unitOfMeasurement = "millimeters?";
call User.RequestTextInput1(message, unitOfMeasurement, &userInput);         //displays "What is the fixture height in millimeters?"

argument2,

InfoMessage
call User.InfoMessage(
message
);

Displays an informative message in the footer.

Parameters
message

the text displayed in the message box

WarningMessage
call User.WarningMessage(
message
);

Displays a warning message in the footer.

Parameters
message

the text displayed in the message box
